Award.AwardTitle: Upgrade of 400 MHz NMR Capabilities for Research, Education and Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities: Multi-user (CRIF:MU) program, Professor Mark Ratner and colleagues Joseph Hupp, Tobin Marks, SonBinh Nguyen and J. Fraser Stoddart from Northwestern University will acquire a 400 MHz spectrometer. The proposal will enhance research training and education at all levels, especially in areas of study such as (a) unlocking the synthetic potential of n-allylhydrazones, (b) bimetallic ethylene polymerization: integrated synthetic, mechanistic, and polymerization studies, and photonics, plasmonics and molecule-based nanomaterials, (c) molecular logic for nanoelectronics, (d) synthesis and characterization of metal-organic frameworks from start to finish, (e) characterization of the surface of colloidal quantum dot (QDs) and its correspondence to their electronic and optical properties, and (f) design and synthesis of novel catalysts for green chemistry and environmental remediation.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to follow the progress of chemical reactions, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solids and in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to carry out frontier chemistry related research and to train students in modern research techniques. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact on organic, materials, electronics, environmental and bioorganic chemistry research at Northwestern University. The instrument will be available to users at other institutions including Harold Washington College and Roosevelt University. The resources will be used not only for research activities but also for research training of undergraduate and graduate students including those from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In developing new technologies and products in this competitive global market, it is inherently necessary to have very close collaboration between research scientists and engineers. These collaborations rely on chemists’ abilities to tap into the wide diversity of existing and as yet undiscovered chemicals rather than relying on commercially available compounds. The synthesis of new compounds fuels studies in the areas of catalysis, chemical biology, medicine, supramolecular chemistry, nanotechnology, drug development, energy storage and materials science at NU. Characterization of these novel compounds by NMR spectroscopy is used to determine connectivity within a molecule and 3D structure.  This characterization is required to develop new chemical reactions, to publish results of new syntheses and evaluate the purity of compounds before applications testing occurs. 

As an example, in the area of alternative fuels, the Hupp group is interested in creating novel material which can be used to safely store large amounts of methane or hydrogen for use in vehicles.  These materials are based on carboxylic acid containing organic ligands bound to metal atoms to create high surface area metal oxide frameworks.  Before the new materials can be tested for gas storage, the organic ligands (Figure 1a) must be synthesized and characterized by multiple NMR techniques and crystals must be grown showing large voids needed for gas storage.  Without adequate NMR capacity, projects such as these will stall at the earliest stages.

This award from NSF-CRIF has enabled the purchase of a new 400 MHz NMR system which is now located in the Technological Institute at Northwestern University (Figure 2).  Prior to this award, NU created the Integrated Molecular Structure Education and Research Center (IMSERC) in 2008 to provide a single site for molecular characterization instrumentation for both sponsored research and hands-on undergraduate education. NU also committed ~$18M to build a new 12,000 sq ft state-of-the-art annex to the Technological Institute that replaced the current 40-year-old facility which IMSERC occupied in mid-2012.  At the time of the award, NU researchers were relying on a 25 year old 500 MHz NMR system that could not be moved to the new site and had already suffered the loss of a 25 year old 400 MHz due to a catastrophic failure.  Since this new instrument has been installed, over 23,000 experiments have been performed supporting over 275 users from 30 research groups.  These experiments have provided data in 20 publications in scientific journals and national meetings.

This instrument also provides a key resource supporting NU's educational mission.   Each year, over 200 undergraduate students taking organic chemistry laboratories use data from the instrument in the laboratory classes. In addition, upper division students receive hands-on training on this instrument.  By providing access to modern NMR instrumentation, NU's undergraduate students are being prepared to enter the workforce in a variety of manners. The typical graduating class of chemistry majors has 35-50 students, with 40% continuing into a chemistry graduate program, 40% going into medical school and the remainder entering industry. The Chem 350 (Advanced Instrumentation and Synthesis), series of classes is designed to give students an overview of modern characterization methods and then execute a research project. Students taking this class consistently provide feedback that their experience with research grade instrumentation in this class has given them a competitive advantage when entering graduate school. In addition, this class shows many students that Chemistry is a high-tech field and encourages more students to pursue higher degrees in Chemistry and other STEM fields.
